DIV1.P: MARGERY; OR, A Worse Plague than the DRAGON: A Burlesque OPERA. As it is Perform'd at the THEATRE-ROYAL in Covent-Garden. Altered from the Original Italian of Signor CARINI. Set to MUSICK By Mr. JOHN-FREDERICK LAMPE.
LONDON: Printed for J. SHUCKBURGH, at the Sun near the Inner-Temple-Gate in Fleet-street, 1738. (Price Six-pence.)

DIV1.HEAD: The ARGUMENT.
DIV1.P:
MAUXALINDA, enraged at the Falshood of MOORE, retires disconsolate to a Desart, unable to bear the Triumphs of her Rival MARGERY (now Lady MOORE) who from the meekest of Creatures, is so elevated with her present Grandeur, that she becomes a very Virago, a worse Plague than the Dragon; and leads her Husband such a confounded Life, that he runs away from her on the very Wedding-Night, and flies, for Quiet-sake, to the De∣sart; where meeting with MAUXALINDA. they renew their former Loves, and grow fonder than ever. Lady MOORE pursues them with the utmost Fury, surprizes them in the beight of their Endearments, and sends MAUXALINDA to Prison. MOORE makes a second Elopement, and sends GUBBINS to re∣lease MAUXALINDA; which being done, GUBBINS, who has long loved her in secret, courts her, and gains her Consent. MOORE
wants to renew his former Acquaintance with MAUXALINDA, but is repuls'd by her, and fu∣riously attack'd by his Lady: After a smart Scolding-Bout they make it up: MOORE is friends with his Lady; GUBBINS is married to MAUXALINDA; and the Opera concludes, according to the Custom of all Operas, with the general Reconciliation of all Parties, no matter how absurd, improbable, or ridiculous.

DIV1.HEAD: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.

LIST.LABEL: Moore of Moore-Hall,
Gaffar Gubbins, Father to Lady Moore,
Lady Moore, formerly Margery Gubbins,
Mauxalinda,
Herald,
First Guest,

DIV1.P: CHORUS of Priests, Huntsmen, Guests, &c. Constable, Jailor, 'Pursuivants; Guards, and other Attendants.

BODY.HEAD: MARGERY; OR, A Worse Plague than the DRAGON.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: A Magnificent Temple finely illumi∣nated, a great Number of Priests, Choristers, &c. Bride-Men, Bride-Maids, &c. &c. Moore and his Lady, Gubbins, Guests, Guards, and other Attendants, &c. &c. &c.

LG.HEAD: CHORUS.
LG.L: Fortune now has done its Duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.P: NOW to Moore-Hall, my Friends, let's haste away, To celebrate this happy Nuptial-Day.

SP.SPEAKER: MAUXALINDA sola.
SP.L: From Moore, and my too happy Rival flown,
Poor Mauxalinda wanders here alone.
Their Bridal Joys are worse than Death to me.
Alas! how cruel is my Destiny!

LG.L: The Swain I adore has undone me;
He woo'd me until he had won me:
He courted me, sure, but to shun me,
And now from his Arms am I thrown.
Come Death, from Distraction relieve me,
Cold Earth to thy Bosom receive me;
Come thou who so basely could'st leave me,
And shed one kind Tear on my Stone.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III. Moore-Hall.
DIV2.STAGE: MOORE and his Lady, GUBBINS, Guests, &c. An Entertainment of Dancing; after which, enter Herald, Pursuivants, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Herald.
SP.L: Most puissant Moore! Our Sovereign Lord the King
Hearing your Fame, which far and near doth ring,
Sends you this Token of his Royal Bounty,
And makes you Lord-Lieutenant of the County:
A Dragon passant guardant is your Arms.
And hearing of your Consort's peerless Charms,
Invites to Court both you and Lady Moore,
Where he has farther Honours yet in store.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: My kind Love to his Majesty, I pray:
We'll just keep Honey-moon, and then away.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: How comes it Mauxalinda is not here,
To grace our Nuptials, and partake our Cheer?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: Methinks, in Manners, you might longer stay;
Can't you forget her on your Wedding-Day?
Ungrateful,—

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: —Daughter, set your Fears aside,
For Mauxalinda, mad with Rage and Pride;
Has, in a Hurry, pack'd up all her Things,
Her Cloaths, her Money, nay, her three Gold Rings,
And went away this Morning by the Carrier.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.P: She's a smart Girl, some Londoner may marry her,

L.HI: Thus the Damsel young and pretty,

LG.L: Takes a Trip to London City,
There she Prudes it so demurely,
And so well displays her Charms,

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: All this is meer Contrivance and Deceit:
With half an Eye I can see through the Cheat.

LG.HEAD: AIR.
LG.L: I'm not to be made such a Tool.
Your Worship shall find me no Fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: I'm all Surprize! What means this sud∣den Change!
'Tis wond'rous odd!

SP.SPEAKER: Gub
SP.L: —'Tis more than odd, 'tis strange!

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Speak to her, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: —Not I, upon my Life:
'Tis dangerous medling betwixt Man and Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Why is my dearest Dear so cross to me?
I wou'd not be so to my Margery.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: It might be Marg'ry Gubbins heretofore;
But now I'll make you know I'm Lady Moore.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Why so thou art:—But yet I hope, my Dear,
If thou art Cap, I may be Button here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: You think you're Master now; but that won't do,
I tell you, I'll be Cap and Button too.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: My Anger rises:—Woman, have a care!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: I scorn your Anger.—Strike me if you dare!

LG.HEAD: AIR.
LG.L: I defy you! I despise you!

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Are these the Joys of Wedlock! This the Life
A Man must lead with an outrageous Wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: Son! keep your Temper;—Let her have her Way,
Brides know their Power on their Wedding-Day.
The Joys they give us wou'd be too com∣pleat,
Did not some Bitter mingle with the Sweet.
This is some female Flight, some jealous Fit.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: You see, my Friends, how 'tis;—I must submit.

LG.HEAD: AIR.
LG.L: Who made the fierce Giants and Monsters to rue,
Was forc'd to rock and reel,
So much cou'd a Woman his Passion subdue.

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: Farewell, Moore-Hall, thou art no Place for Stay:
O, Friends! this is a dismal Wedding-Day!

SP.SPEAKER: MOORE solus.
SP.L: FArewell, Moore-Hall—I now have broke my Chain,
I never more will darken thee again.
This Woman has a Spirit wou'd scare the Devil;
Tygers and Wolves, compar'd to her, are civil.
Alas! what mighty Deeds have I to brag on?
I'm more afraid of her, than of the Dragon.
Sooner in Desarts with wild Beasts I'll dwell,
Than with that Wife, who makes my Home a Hell.

LG.HEAD: AIR.
LG.L: Was ever Man so much deceiv'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: Cruel Swain!—

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: What tender, plaintive Sounds invade my Ear?
Sure Melancholy's self inhabits here:
Approach, sweet Warbler! thou perhaps may'st be
Some easy cred'lous Wretch, deceiv'd like me;
I'll not obstruct, but listen to thy Moan,
Then mingle, with thy soft Complaints, my own.
SP.STAGE: Retires to a Corner of the Stage.

LG.HEAD: AIR.
LG.L: Cruel Swain, since you forsake me,
I'll to lonely Shades betake me,

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Come to my Arms, thou Treasure of Delight.
SP.STAGE: Goes to embrace her, she flies back.

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: What new Device is this, to mock my Grief?
Experience now has banish'd all Belief.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: I own my Crime; O pardon my Of∣fence;
I'm all Consusion, Shame and Penitence.

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: O Moore! I lov'd you as I did my Life—
I'd fain believe you, but you've got a Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Oh! name her not.—With thee, my Love, I'll fly
Far as the utmost Verge of Earth or Sky:
We'll traverse ev'ry Sea, and ev'ry Shore,
And ne'er approach that hated Object more.

LG.HEAD: DUETTO.
LG.L: Around the wide World we will wander,
Grow fonder, and fonder, and fonder;
And kiss the cold Winter away.
When Sol's sultry Heat does invade us,
Green Osiers and Willows shall shade us.
And frolick it all the long Day.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE II. Gubbins's House.
DIV2.STAGE: GUBBINS and Guests as from Drinking.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Guest.
SP.L: Thanks, noble Gubbins, for this Night's Repast:—
I think we've fairly made it out at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: But why so hasty, why so soon away?
Another Bottle will bring on the Day.

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: What's this I see?—My Daughter!—
Say, my Dear!
What brings thee thus unseasonably here?
How could'st thou quit so soon the Bridal Bed?
A Sigh too! Tell me, is thy Husband dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: Oh! ten times worse!

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: —How can that be?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: —He's fled.

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: What! before Consummation?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: Ay, to my great Vexation.

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: O Daughter, Daughter! if I right con∣jecture,
He ran away, to 'scape a Curtain-Lecture.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: No, he has Mauxalinda in his Mind:
Now she is gone, he cannot stay behind.

LG.L: When not Rage, or yet Submission,
Or to Virtue bring him over.
When she sees her self neglected,
Oh! how great must be her Anguish!
Who can blame her then to languish. Wretched, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: He's sadly off; for she, like thee, I fear,
May have a Tongue too many for his Ear.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: Unhappy me! I came to be redrest,
And you, I see, make all my Wrongs your Jest:
But I'll, through all the Courts of Law pur∣sue him;
I'll rumage Hell it self, but I'll undo him:
I'll issue out Reward by Proclamation,
And have him, if he's living in the Nation.

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: Well said, my Girl—thy Mother's Daughter still;
She had a Tongue most exquisitely shrill.
But hark! the jolly Huntsman's Horn
Gives Notice of approaching Morn:
Let's lose no Moment of Delight,
But hunt all Day, as we have drank all Night.

LG.HEAD: AIR.
LG.L: Come follow, brave Boys, to the Chace,
For Morning breaks on us apace;
The Fogs and the Mist disappear,
The Hounds are uncoupled, then hast and away,
You'll lose all the Sport, if you longer de∣lay.
What, what are your Opera's to me,
No Musick, that's under the Sky,
Can equal the Hounds at full Cry.
Then a Fig for Italians, their Squeak and their Squawl,
One true English Sportsman shall dumb∣found 'em all.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III. The Desart.

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: By these Arms, that round thee twine
Like the ever-circling Vine:
By this tender fond Embrace,
Nothing shall my Love efface.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: By the Nectar, which I sip
From thy soft and ruby Lip,
Never, never will I leave thee,
Never, never more deceive thee.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lady MOORE with Constable, Guards, &c. and surprizes 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: So, so, my pretty Turtles, are you there—
I've caught you napping, as Moss caught his Mare.
Sir, that's your Prisoner—
Take my Lady Stock,
Make her beat Hemp, and chain her to the Block.
SP.STAGE: Mauxalinda is carried off; Moore strives to follow, but is pre∣vented by his Lady.
SP.L: For you, Sir Knight, come Home, and mind your Duty;
I'll teach you to run rambling after Beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: O ungrateful! to deceive me,
Thus to rob me of Content.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: O most hateful! leave me, leave me,
You my Anger but augment.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: Faithless Traytor!

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Plague of Nature!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: Where's your Conscience?

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Curse your Nonsense!
Let me go, Let me go.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: No, no, no; No, no, no.
O ungrateful, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: OH, Sir! here's been a most con∣founded Rout—
Mauxy's in Hold, and you must bring her out.
As she and I, like Turtles of a feather,
Were cooing in the Wilderness together,
My Lady came with Possé Comitatus,
And sent poor Mauxalinda to the Gate-house.

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: I cannot bear she should a Prisoner be—
I'll tear the Jail down, but I'll set her free

SP.SPEAKER: MOORE solus.
SP.L: Was ever Man so hamper'd with a Wife?
Patience, ye Gods! but I am link'd for Life:
The Knot's too fast, 'tis needless to complain;
I wish the Dragon were alive again.

LG.L: When he fills all the Forest with Dread,
Is a Lamb to a Woman enrag'd,
If once Jealousy gets in her Head.
Her Soul's on a Ferment of Fury,
No soothing the Tempest can still;
She values no Law, Judge or Jury,

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE II. A Prison.

SP.L: So, Madam,—How d'ye like your stately Lodging?
Is not this better than in Desarts dodging?

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: Madam, I see through all your saucy Sneer—
You may provoke my Scorn, but not my Fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: Your boasted Courage I'm resolv'd to try.
Behold this Dagger, and prepare to die.

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: Since you've robb'd me of my Trea∣sure,
Lise is now no more a Pleasure:
Death is welcome ev'n from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: Since you've robb'd me of my Treasure,
In your Death is all my Pleasure:
Vengeance, Vengeance is my Due.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Gubbins with Jailor and Guards.

SP.L: Daughter, forbear, and let your Fury cease;
For know I'm come poor Mauxy to release.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: My Father too my Foe! Patience is vain

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: Marg'ry thy Pride, I think, has turn'd thy Brain.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: I'll be reveng'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: —Nay, if she makes a Riot,
Jailor, secure her, 'till she grows more quiet.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MOORE sola.
SP.L: This is enough to make a Woman mad—
I'll be reveng'd, if Vengeance can be had.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III. Gubbins's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: This wond'rous Goodness how can I repay!

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: Oh! you shall make it up another way.
Sweet Mauxalinda, if you can forsake
All other Men for Gaffar Gubbins' sake,
And prove to him a true and faithful Wife,
With all I have I'll Jointure thee for Life.

LG.HEAD: AIR.
LG.L: Does my Soul of Souls inslave;
For her Charm of Charms expiring,

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: Since they've depriv'd me of my dear∣est Knight,
I'll marry Gubbins merely out of Spight.
And when I'm Madam Marg'ry's Mother-in-Law,
By Jove, I'll keep her Ladyship in awe.

LG.HEAD: AIR.
LG.L: Then come to my Arms, old Dad,
And fondle thine own dear Honey:
If Love is too late to be had,
Let's make up the Loss with Money.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: Why Father, what d'ye mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: —What's that to you?
I'm old enough to know what 'tis I do.
O joyful Sight! my Mauxalinda freed!
Thanks noble Gubbins for this gen'rous Deed:
O let me clasp thee to my Arms.

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: —Not so—
She's now My Mauxalinda, you must know.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: How can you bear the Loss of one so dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: My Plague! my Bane! my Evil Genius here!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: I come, Sir, a Wife my Right to claim?

SP.SPEAKER: Moore
SP.L: Of me you shall have nothing but the Name.
No Nuptial Kindness?—

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: —Not one single Kiss.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: Barbarian, did'st thou marry me for this?

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Henceforth no Husband hope to find of me,
'Till you more gentle and submissive be.
Beneath one Roof, with each a sep'rate Bed,
We'll live polite—and wish each other dead.
O, Sir! your Looks, your Words have riv'd my Heart—
No other Punishment, but Beds to part?—
See at your Feet, your Pardon I implore;
I never will provoke your Anger more.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: What Farce is this!—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: —No Farce, my dearest Life,
But a Converted and Obedient Wife.

LG.HEAD: AIR.
LG.L: Your Content shall crown my Care.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Come to my Arms, thou Treasure of my Life,
Henceforth my best belov'd, and dearest Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: And now, my Marg'ry, may'st thou ever be
As kind to Moore, as he is fond of thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: I wish you Joy, Sir! May she ever be
As true to you—as you have been to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: Why now all's right.—Call all the Country in;
Keep Open-House, and let the Sports begin.

DIV2.STAGE: An Entertainment of Dancing; after∣wards Moore comes forward.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Henceforth let Discord and Dissention cease,
While we all live in Harmony and Peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: And have of Wealth and Children great Increase.

LG.HEAD: CHORUS.
LG.L: Strain your Voices, crack your Strings;
He sings best, who loudest sings.
Blow your Cheeks of Sound away,
